newsitem.title: INDIA: India's BSE cancels Bank of Baroda trades.
newsitem.headline: India's BSE cancels Bank of Baroda trades.

text.p: The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) on Friday cancelled transactions in shares of state-run Bank of Baroda which were listed earlier in the day, brokers said.
They said BSE had flashed an announcement on their online trading systems which said transactions conducted on Friday in shares of Bank of Baroda had been annulled.
The exchange had earlier suspended the shares due to confusion arising from the simultaneous listing of its partly- and fully-paid shares.
Brokers said early trade was confused as most investors were unsure which price quotes reflected the shares they held. Both shares listed at around 35 rupees.
In its initial public offer last December, the bank issued 100 million shares of 10 rupees face value at 85 rupees a share.
For retail investors, employees and banks, Bank of Baroda collected 25 rupees on application and 25 rupees on allotment. The balance will be collected later in the year.
Shares issued to non-resident Indians, overseas corporate bodies and foreign institutional investors were fully-paid shares at 85 rupees each.
